Exaggerate: The claim may be exaggerating the rate of sexual assault reports involving ridesharing drivers, as the expert's verdict suggests that the quoted statement of "one per month" is an undercount and does not include all reported cases.
Understate: The claim may be understating the actual number of sexual assault reports involving ridesharing drivers, as the expert's verdict mentions that the quoted statement of "one per month" is an undercount and there may be more cases that go unreported or are reported to other organizations or the police.
Lack enough support: The claim may lack enough support as the expert's verdict questions the basis of the quoted statement and mentions that it originated from supportive women, not the group itself. Additionally, it is mentioned that the rate of one per month is an undercount and does not include all reported cases.
Problematic assumption: The claim may make a problematic assumption that all sexual assault survivors reporting attacks by ridesharing drivers are accurately represented by the cases seen in the offices of Stop Abuse for Everyone. The expert's verdict mentions that many cases go unreported or are reported to other organizations or the police, suggesting that the claim may not capture the full extent of the issue.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim may have an alternative explanation, as the expert's verdict mentions that the letter was a fundraising effort by opponents of a May 2016 Austin ballot proposition affecting drivers for ride-hailing services. This suggests that the claim could be influenced by a biased perspective or agenda.
